questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with jaundice and fatigue, recently diagnosed with hepatitis B infection. Further investigation reveals abnormal liver function tests, indicating hepatic injury. Which of the following statements regarding the mechanisms of hypersensitivity involved in this case is true?

options.label: A
options.text: CD8+ T cells differentiate into Th1 and Th17 cells upon antigen exposure

options.label: B
options.text: CD4+ T cells differentiate into Th2 cells upon exposure to antigen

options.label: C
options.text: Cytotoxic T-lymphocytes (CTLs) directly kill virus-infected cells via the Fas-Fas ligand pathway

options.label: D
options.text: Perforin-granzyme-dependent killing is a mechanism employed by CD4+ T cells

questions.correct_answer: C. Cytotoxic T-lymphocytes (CTLs) directly kill virus-infected cells via the Fas-Fas ligand pathway
questions.explanation:
Mechanisms of Type IV hypersensitivity

Description

Examples

Cytokine-mediated inflammation
(mediated by CD4+ T cells)

CD4+ T cells recognise protein antigens presented by APCs and differentiate into Th1 and Th17 cells (Options A and B ruled out).

Th1 cells secrete cytokines like IFN-γ, activating macrophages to cause tissue damage and fibrosis. Th17 cells produce IL-17 to recruit neutrophils, promoting inflammation.
  • Tuberculin test (a classic example of delayed-type hypersensitivity)
  • Granulomas
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • IBD
  • Psoriasis

T cell-mediated cytotoxicity (mediated by CD8+ T cells)


 

Cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) directly kill antigen-bearing target cells, including tumour cells, virus-infected cells, and allogeneic tissue, during graft rejection. CTLs use perforin-granzyme-dependent killing (Option D ruled out) and Fas-Fas ligand-dependent killing mechanisms to induce apoptosis in target cells. (Option C)
  • Type 1 DM
  • Hepatic injury in HBV infection
  • Graft vs host disease

questions.text: A 7 Y/O boy presents with a limp and complains of pain in his right hip that has gradually worsened over the past few weeks. The pain is sometimes referred to his knee.There is no history of trauma.On physical examination, there is a limited range of motion, particularly in internal rotation and abduction of the hip.X-ray of the pelvis shows flattening of the femoral head with areas of sclerosis and fragmentation.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Idiopathic osteonecrosis or idiopathic avascular necrosis of the capital femoral epiphysis of the femoral head.

Etiopathogenesis
  • Idiopathic or etiology that would disrupt the blood flow to femoral epiphysis.
  • Coagulopathy and steroid use.
 

Includes 4 phases

  • Necrosis: Disruption of the blood supply leads to infarction of the femoral capital epiphysis.
  • Fragmentation: The body reabsorbs the infarcted bone.
  • Reossification: Osteoblastic activity takes over, and the femoral epiphysis reestablishes.
  • Remodeling: The new femoral head may be enlarged or flattened. It reshapes during growth.

Risk factors
  • Ten percent familial (there is a delayed bone age by about 2 years)
  • HIV (Up to 5% of HIV patients have avascular necrosis of the hip)
  • Factor V Leiden
  • Thrombophilias (increased clotting)
  • Hypofibrinolysis (decreased ability to dissolve clots)
  • Secondhand smoke exposure
  • Low socioeconomic status
  • Birth weight less than 2.5 kg in boys
  • Short stature

Clinical features
  • Limp of acute or insidious onset, usually painless.
  • If pain is present, it is localized to the hip or knee.
  • Decreased internal rotation and abduction of hip.
  • Atrophy of thighs and buttocks.
  • Leg length discrepancy.
  • Antalgic gait in acute cases
  • Trendelenburg gait in chronic cases

Diagnosis
  • Standard anteroposterior pelvis and frog-leg lateral (Lauenstein) views.
  • Bone scan or MRI


 

Early findings:

  • Widening of joint space (epiphyseal cartilage hypertrophy)
  • Changes in the epiphysis.
  • Crescent sign: Subchondral radiolucent zone of the anterolateral epiphysis
 

Late signs:

  • Flattening of the femoral head.
  • Bone scan shows decreased perfusion to the femoral head.

Differential diagnosis
  • Transient synovitis
  • Multiple epiphyseal dysplasia (MED)
  • Spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia (SED)
  • Gaucher disease
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Meyer dysplasia

Treatment

Non operative:

  • Indicated for children with bone age less than 6 or lateral pillar A involvement.
  • Activity restriction and protective weight-bearing are recommended until ossification is complete.
 

Operative treatment:

  • Femoral or Pelvic Osteotomy indicated in children older than 8 years.
  • Valgus or Shelf Osteotomies indicated in children with hinge abduction
  • Hip Arthroscopy

Complications
  • Coxa magna: Widening of the femoral head.
  • Coda plans: Flattening of the femoral head.

Comedo

    • Tumor cells with pleomorphic, high-grade nuclei.

Cribriform

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient is diagnosed with malignant pheochromocytoma after presenting with persistent hypertension and elevated plasma metanephrines. Imaging reveals metastasis to various sites. Which of the following is not a common site for metastasis?
questions.explanation:
Malignant Pheochromocytoma

Tumors that have undergone metastasis to Lymph-node (or) Distant site (Biochemically same as Pheochromocytoma)

Survival Rate

5-year survival ranges from 20% to 45%.

Criteria of Malignancy

Malignancy is defined by the development of metastases

Common Sites of Metastasis

Axial skeleton, lymph nodes, liver, lung, and kidney. (Option A,C,D)

Diagnosis

  • MIBG & Gallium Dotate is Best for Diagnosis
  • Biopsy & FNAC are avoided in Malignant Pheochromocytoma
  • Confirmed by the presence of metastases in locations where neuroectodermal tissues are not normally found.
  • This is the primary criterion distinguishing malignant pheochromocytomas from benign ones, as histopathologic features alone are not reliable in predicting malignancy.

Histopathologic Criteria

No histopathologic criteria can accurately predict the clinical course of malignancy.

Primary Treatment

Surgical resection, even if not curative, can offer significant palliative benefits by managing mass effects and reducing catecholamine excess.

Response to Radiotherapy/Chemotherapy

Minimal response to radiotherapy and chemotherapy.

questions.text: A forensic scientist is analyzing a DNA sample from a crime scene. The DNA is digested with restriction enzymes, separated by gel electrophoresis, and transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane. Labeled DNA probes are then used to detect specific fragments. Which technique is the scientist most likely using?
questions.explanation:
Sequential Steps involved using RFLP technique 
 

1. DNA Digestion

DNA is cut by restriction enzymes at specific sites.
 

2. Electrophoresis

DNA fragments are separated by size using gel electrophoresis.
 

3. Denaturation

To enable probe binding, the separated fragments are denatured
 

4. Southern Blotting

Fragments are transferred from the gel to a nitrocellulose membrane.
 

5. Hybridization

DNA fragments hybridize with labeled DNA probes.
 

6. Visualization

Hybridized fragments are visualized to reveal the presence or absence of restriction sites.

questions.text: Identify the correct option.

The following are some steps taken to investigate an epidemic. Arrange the steps in the correct sequence. Verification of the diagnosis. Define the population at risk. Data analysis. Confirmation of the existence of an epidemic. Evaluation of ecological factors. Testing of hypothesis.
questions.explanation:
Steps

Salient points

1

Verification of diagnosis
  • Most important step
  • Examination of a sample of cases and verify the diagnosis
  • To avoid a spurious diagnosis based on signs and symptoms.

2

Confirmation of the existence of an epidemic
  • Compare data collected with the previous year's data.
  • Epidemic:
    • Occurrence > 2 S.D.
    • The cases occur at over 80% of the expected frequency.

3

Defining the population at risk
  • Obtain a map of the area affected.
  • A house-to-house survey is done to find the entire population at risk.

4

Rapid search for all cases and their characteristics
  • Medical survey.
  • Epidemiological case sheet.

5

Data analysis
  • Done in terms of Time, Place and person
  • Try to identify the type of epidemic by drawing the epidemic curve.

6

Formulation of hypothesis
  • It contains information about the agent, host, environment, modes of transmission, etc.
  • Formulation of a hypothesis is the work of descriptive epidemiology.

7

Testing of hypothesis
  • First step: Case-control study.
  • Second step: Plan a cohort study to compare the attack rates in exposed vs non-exposed groups.

8

Evaluation of ecological factors
  • Effect of humidity.
  • Effect of sanitary conditions.
  • Effect of water supply.

9

Further investigation of the population at risk
  • Keep looking for any other population that is at risk.

10

Writing the report
  • To provide a strategy at the end.
  • Prevent future occurrences.

R

Radial Artery
  • Supplies the myometrium ( inner ⅔)

B

questions.text: In a rural village, trachoma remains a significant public health concern. A public health officer is tasked with implementing a comprehensive prevention strategy for trachoma. Match each intervention with the appropriate level of prevention: 1. Primary Prevention a. Coordinates surgical treatment for blindness 2. Secondary Prevention b. Promotes facial cleanliness and sanitation. 3. Tertiary Prevention c. Ensures antibiotics are prescribed only to confirmed cases. 4. Quaternary Prevention d. Conduct regular eye screenings.
questions.explanation:
Levels of Prevention

Description

Measures

Primary Prevention

Interventions before the onset of the disease to avert its occurrence by addressing the pre-pathogenesis phase.

Promotes facial cleanliness and sanitation to prevent trachoma.

Secondary Prevention

Aim to halt disease progression in its early stages and prevent complications through timely diagnosis (e.g., screening, case-finding) and prompt, appropriate treatment.

Conduct regular eye screenings to detect and treat trachoma early.

Tertiary Prevention

Focuses on minimizing the impact of existing health conditions by reducing impairments and disabilities, alleviating suffering, and promoting adjustment to irreversible states.

Coordinates surgical treatment for those with trachoma-related blindness.

Quaternary Prevention

Promoting evidence-based practices to prevent over diagnosis and offering ethically validated treatment options

Ensures antibiotics are prescribed only to confirmed cases to avoid unnecessary treatment.

questions.text: Based on the image, identify the structures indicated by the arrows

options.label: A
options.text: Yellow: Sequestrum, White: Cloaca, Red: Involucrum

options.label: B
options.text: Yellow: Involucrum, White: Sequestrum, Red: Cloaca

options.label: C
options.text: Yellow: Cloaca, White: Involucrum, Red: Sequestrum

options.label: D
options.text: Yellow: Sequestrum, White: Involucrum, Red: Cloaca

questions.correct_answer: D. Yellow: Sequestrum, White: Involucrum, Red: Cloaca
questions.explanation:
Sequestrum

Involucrum

Cloaca
  • Definition: A piece of dead bone separated from living bone due to infection.
  • Formation: Occurs in neglected cases of acute osteomyelitis, resulting from tissue destruction.
  • Characteristics: Size varies; can range from small spicules to large necrotic segments of the cortex.
  • Clinical Significance: Remains entombed within the bone, inaccessible for destruction or repair.
  • Definition: New bone formation around the infected zone.
  • Formation: Develops on viable surfaces in the bone and from the deep layers of the stripped periosteum.
  • Characteristics: Initially porotic, becomes thicker to form a casing around the sequestrum and infected tissue.
  • Clinical Significance: Can help enclose and isolate the infection, but may lead to permanent deformity if healing is inadequate.
  • Definition: Perforations in the involucrum that allow discharge of pus and bone debris.
  • Formation: Develops as the infection persists, leading to small openings through which material can escape.
  • Characteristics: Creates a path for the pus to track through sinuses to the skin surface.
  • Clinical Significance: Indicates the chronicity of osteomyelitis, leading to intermittent discharge through sinuses.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of AIDS presents to the clinic with persistent fever, significant weight loss over the past month, and cough that has worsened over the last two weeks. He resides in a rural area of Southeast Asia, where he frequently encounters bamboo rats. On physical examination, he has cervical lymphadenopathy and hepatomegaly. A sputum sample is collected for microbiological examination. An image is shown below. Which of the following is characteristic of the colony that is likely to grow in culture from this patient’s sputum sample?

options.label: B
options.text: Green, granular colonies with a distinctive red pigment

options.label: D
options.text: Creamy white, smooth colonies and with a yeasty odour

questions.correct_answer: B. Green, granular colonies with a distinctive red pigment
questions.explanation:
Penicillium marneffei

Characteristics

Currently, the name is changed to Talaromyces marneffei.

Thermally dimorphic fungus

Causes

Talaromycosis (Penicilliosis)

Epidemiology

Common in Southeast Asia, southern China, and northeastern India.

High incidence in AIDS and immunocompromised patients.

Reservoir

Bamboo rat

Route of transmission

Inhalation of fungal spores

No person-to-person transmission

Clinical manifestations

It affects the reticuloendothelial system, causing lymphadenopathy, hepatomegaly, and splenomegaly.

Lung involvement is common.

Increased risk of dissemination in AIDS and immunocompromised individuals.

Specimens for Diagnosis

Bone marrow, blood, sputum, lymph nodes, skin lesions

Diagnosis

Culture on Sabouraud Agar:

  • Green, granular colonies with a distinctive red pigment that diffuses into the agar.

Microscopy:

  • Septate hyphae with branched conidiophores

showing a brush-like arrangement of spores

 

Additional Tests:

  • Antigen testing (urine/serum) and PCR

Treatment

Amphotericin B (IV for two weeks), followed by Itraconazole.

Others: Voriconazole, Posaconazole.

A patient has a urine concentration of a substance of 10 mg/mL, a urine flow rate of 2 mL/min, and a plasma concentration of that substance of 5 mg/mL. What is the clearance rate of this substance?
questions.explanation:
Inulin Clearance
  • Used to measure Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) as it is freely filtered but not reabsorbed or secreted.
  • Not ideal for routine use due to intravenous administration.

Creatinine Clearance
  • Estimates GFR using creatinine, which is primarily filtered by the glomeruli.
  • Slightly inaccurate due to tubular secretion, but practical for clinical settings.

PAH Clearance
  • Estimates Renal Plasma Flow (RPF).
  • PAH is cleared through both glomerular filtration and tubular secretion.
  • Correction for PAH extraction ratio improves accuracy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with hot flashes, night sweats, and irregular menstrual cycles, suggesting a decrease in estrogen levels. Which of the following is a primary source of estrogen in premenopausal women, and which of the following is an effect of estrogen on the body?

options.label: A
options.text: Adrenal cortex; Maintenance of bone density

questions.correct_answer: C. Granulosa cells, proliferation of endometrium
questions.explanation:
Estrogen

Progesterone

Source

Granulosa cells (Option C), corpus luteum, and placenta

Corpus luteum, placenta and ovarian follicles

Effects on female genitalia
  • Growth of ovarian follicle
  • Proliferation of endometrium (Option C)
  • Increase the motility of the uterine tubes
  • Increase blood flow in the uterus
  • Increase the amount of uterine muscle and contractility.
  • Antiestrogenic effect on the myometrium, decreasing their excitability
  • Secretory effect on the endometrium

Female Secondary Sex Characteristics
  • Enlargement of breasts
  • Female distribution of fat
  • Wide carrying angle
  • Stimulates the development of lobules and alveoli

Effects on the Central Nervous System
  • Increase libido
  • Increase the proliferation of dendrites on neurons and the number of synaptic knobs
  • Thermogenic and responsible for the rise in basal body temperature during ovulation

Effects on Endocrine Organs
  • Increased secretion of angiotensinogen and thyroid-binding globulin
  • Large doses of progesterone inhibit LH secretion and potentiate the inhibitory effect of estrogens, preventing ovulation.

Other effects
  • Retention of salt and water and gain weight just before menstruation
  • Plasma cholesterol-lowering action
  • Vasodilation by increasing the local production of NO.
  • Maintains bone mineral density
  • Stimulates respiration, and the alveolar PCO2
  • Increases plasma LDL and decreases HDL (Option D)

Given below are a few statements on various kinds of autopsy. Which of them is true? A psychological autopsy is done after suicide. Virtopsy combines 2D surface scanning/CAD photogrammetry with radiologic imaging like MRI. Psychological autopsy involves data collection. The ability to identify the infection status of antemortem from postmortem wounds is limited in Virtopsy. Easy to identify postmortem artifacts using Virtopsy
questions.explanation:
Virtual autopsy/Virtopsy

Virtopsy is a non-invasive alternative to traditional autopsy using imaging instead of physical dissection.

Technology
  • Utilizes 3D surface scanning, MSCT, MRI, and CAD photogrammetry to create a digital, objective record. (Option D)
  • This can be shared online for secondary opinions and presented as evidence in court if required.

Features
  • Provides high-resolution, colored 3D images in various sections
  • Allows visualization of body surfaces, deeper tissues, organs, coronary vessels, pulmonary emboli, soft tissue trauma, and bone injuries

Limitations
  • High cost of equipment
  • Radiologic imaging limitations, interference from metal
  • Limited ability to distinguish internal organ colors
  • Incomplete database for diagnosis
  • Challenges in identifying infection status, antemortem vs. postmortem wounds (Options B and C ruled out)
  • Difficulty in identifying postmortem artifacts and subtle tissue injuries, and differentiating certain pathological conditions (Option D)

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman at 34 weeks of gestation presents for a routine prenatal visit. She reports no pain, contractions, or bleeding. An ultrasound performed at 20 weeks showed a placenta previa that remained stable on follow-up ultrasound. What should be the next step in the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate hospitalisation and preparation for emergency C-section

options.label: B
options.text: Expectant management with periodic transvaginal ultrasounds (TVS) and implementation of the McAfee Johnson regimen

options.label: C
options.text: Administration of magnesium sulfate for fetal neuroprotection and immediate delivery

options.label: D
options.text: Routine follow-up with monthly abdominal ultrasounds without activity restrictions

questions.correct_answer: B. Expectant management with periodic transvaginal ultrasounds (TVS) and implementation of the McAfee Johnson regimen
questions.explanation:
Indications:
  • The mother is healthy (Hb >10 g % and haematocrit > 30%).
  • Absence of active vaginal bleeding.
  • Gestational age <37 weeks.
  • Reactive CTG.

Steps in McAfee and Johnson regime:
  1. Hospitalise the patient (Bed rest).
  2. Monitoring:
    1. Maternal vitals.
    2. Fetal heart sounds.
    3. Bleeding.
  3. Arrange for blood.
  4. If the patient is Rh (-ve), anti-D should be given.
  5. Injection of corticosteroids to hasten lung maturity of the fetus.
  6. Short-term tocolytic (nifedipine) should be provided if any contractions are present.
  7. If pregnancy <32 weeks: MgSO4 (neural protection).
 

The above-mentioned steps are continued till 37 weeks, after which elective cesarean section can be done.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with dysphagia, throat pain, and a palpable neck mass. Laryngoscopy reveals a lesion on the epiglottis. Further investigations lead to the diagnosis of Laryngeal carcinoma.Which of the following is not a typical characteristic of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Bilateral lymph node metastases are common but occurs late

options.label: B
options.text: Hoarseness is usually a late symptom

options.label: C
options.text: The most common histological type is squamous cell carcinoma

options.label: D
options.text: It may spread to the pre-epiglottic space

questions.correct_answer: A. Bilateral lymph node metastases are common but occurs late
questions.explanation:
Incidence

Less frequent than glottic cancer; about 30-35% of all laryngeal cancers

Site

Majority on epiglottis, false cords, followed by aryepiglottic folds

Vocal cord involvement

Usually late; vocal cords often spared in early stages

Lymphatic spread
  • Early and often bilateral
  • Upper and middle jugular nodes commonly involved
  • Cancer of infrahyoid epiglottis & anterior ventricular band may extend into pre-epiglottic space (Option D)

Symptoms
  • Early: Often silent, dysphagia, throat pain
  • Late: Hoarseness, weight loss, respiratory obstruction, halitosis (Option B)

Histopathology
  • 90-95% squamous cell carcinoma (Option C)
  • Others include verrucous carcinoma, spindle cell carcinoma
  • Highly anaplastic

Prognosis

Generally worse than glottic cancer due to:

  • Late diagnosis
  • High rate & early lymph node metastasis
  • Anaplastic nature

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with a 2-week history of worsening bilateral eye redness, itching, and frequent lacrimation. On examination, hypertrophied, cobblestone-like papillae is seen on the palpebral conjunctiva. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Vernal keratoconjunctivitis or Spring catarrh

It is a recurrent bilateral conjunctivitis that tends to occur with the onset of warm weather. It primarily affects young children and adolescents, particularly boys.

Course

The condition typically starts in childhood and may resolve on its own over 5–10 years.

Symptoms

Burning, Itching, Photophobia (sensitivity to light), and lacrimation (excessive tearing).

Signs
  • Palpebral Form: Hypertrophied palpebral conjunctiva with a cobblestone appearance;dense fibrous tissue with thickened epithelium.
  • Limbal or Bulbar Form: Opacification at the limbus, gelatinous thickening, and Horner–Trantas dots
  • Pseudogerontoxon/cupid’s bow (which resembles arcus senilis) is a grayish-white ring at the limbus seen in severe limbal vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC).
 
  • Shield ulcers are a significant complication of VKC, particularly in severe cases. These microerosions typically form on the upper third of the cornea.
 
  • Mixed form: Exhibits characteristics of both the tarsal (palpebral) and limbal subtypes, typically presenting in only one eye.
 

Maxwell Lyon's sign is a pseudomembrane formed due to excessive mucus deposition on the papilla resulting in cobblestone papillae.

Histology

In the palpebral form, hypertrophied papillae are observed, rich in eosinophils and other inflammatory cells.

Treatment
  • Topical therapy:
    • Antihistamines - Levocabastine & emedastine
    • Mast cell stabilizers - Sodium cromoglicate
    • Mild steroids - Fluorometholone and loteprednol etabonate,
    • Acetylcysteine can control excess mucus.
  • Local therapy: Subtarsal steroid injections and cryotherapy for severe cases.
  • Surgical treatment: Excision of giant papillae and treatment of shield ulcers with debridement and amniotic membrane or bandage contact lens.
  • Cold compresses and tinted glasses for comfort.
  • Avoid eye rubbing

A 62-year-old male with asthma presents to the emergency department with worsening shortness of breath and wheezing. He is placed on supplemental oxygen and bronchodilators. What is the most likely Capnographic waveform for this patient?
questions.explanation:
A normal wave in controlled mechanical ventilation

 

Normal wave during spontaneous breathing

Bronchospasm (asthma, COPD exacerbation) / partially obstructed ET tube or breathing circuit

  • Shark fin appearance

 

Spontaneous breathing effort during controlled mechanical ventilation (Curare notch)

  • Curare cleft, or notch, is seen during spontaneous ventilation.
  • Patients partially paralyzed with muscle relaxants may make respiratory efforts at any time during the respiratory cycle with controlled ventilation.
  • As the muscle relaxant is reversed, the curve becomes normal in shape. (Option D ruled out)

 

Role in Intubation:

  • End tidal is used as the gold standard for confirmation of endotracheal tube position.
  • Esophageal intubation can initially produce an EtCO2 due to gastric CO2 however this should taper after a few breaths.
  • Right main-stem intubation may still have a normal EtCO2, so get a CXR to confirm optimal tube positioning.

Role during Cardiac Arrest:

  • EtCO2 > 20 suggests good quality CPR.
  • If it starts to drop, consider switching compressors or making sure the LUCUS is in the appropriate position.
  • A sudden increase in EtCO2 greater than 10 from the patient’s baseline can be an early indication of ROSC.

Hypoventilation (Option A ruled out)

Hyperventilation (Option B ruled out)

Flat Capnogram: Sudden and abrupt fall of EtCO2 to zero can be seen in:

  • Accidental extubation (most common)
  • Disconnection of CO2 transducer
  • Sudden cardiac arrest
  • Massive pulmonary embolism

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a severe migraine headache that has been ongoing for several hours. She reports that her headache is accompanied by nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. She has tried over-the-counter pain relievers without relief. What medication would you prescribe to help alleviate her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Mechanism of Action
  • It is a selective 5-HT1B/1D receptor agonist that activates other subtypes of 5-HT1 receptors only at very high concentrations.
  • Inhibits the release of calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) and causes cranial vasoconstriction.

Administration and Efficacy
  • It is administered at the onset of a migraine attack and is as effective and better tolerated than ergotamine.
  • About 3/4 of patients obtain complete or significant relief within 2-3 hours.
  • Available in various formulations such as Oral tablets, Nasal sprays, Injections and Rectal suppositories.

Pharmacokinetics
  • It is absorbed rapidly and completely after subcutaneous injection, with an oral bioavailability of only 15%.
  • It is rapidly metabolised by MAO-A isoenzyme, and metabolites are excreted in urine, with an elimination half-life of approximately 2 hours.

Side Effects
  • Common side effects include tightness in the head and chest, feeling of heat and other paresthesias in the limbs, dizziness, and weakness. These are usually mild and short-lasting but can be dose-related.

A 28 y/o woman, G2P2, presents to the emergency on postpartum day 10 with complaints of vaginal bleeding. She reports with fever, chills, and feels lightheaded and weak. O/E, the uterus is larger than expected for her postpartum state, and there is moderate vaginal bleeding. Her hemoglobin level is 7.8 g/dL. All of the following can cause postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) in this patient, EXCEPT:
questions.explanation:
Secondary Postpartum Hemorrhage

Cause

Description

Retained Placental Fragments and Membranes (Option A)
  • Most common cause
  • They can prevent proper uterine involution and healing, leading to significant bleeding.
  • Rarely, retained products undergo necrosis and fibrin deposition, forming a placental polyp that can cause severe hemorrhage.

Infection

Tissue breakdown and delayed healing

Endometritis (Option C)
  • Inflammation of the uterine lining and delayed healing.
  • Symptoms typically include fever, uterine tenderness, and foul-smelling lochia.

Subinvolution of Placental Site
  • Uterus's failure to return to its normal size after delivery.
  • When the placental site heals slowly, it can increase the risk of secondary bleeding

Uterine artery Pseudoaneurysm (Option D)

  • A severe but rare cause of secondary PPH.
  • It occurs when a pseudoaneurysm forms in the uterine artery, leading to delayed hemorrhage.

options.label: B
options.text: It is the most common cause of vasculitis in adults

options.label: C
options.text: It occurs as a result of a B cell-mediated immune response

options.label: D
options.text: It is associated with polymyalgia rheumatica

questions.correct_answer: C. It occurs as a result of a B cell-mediated immune response
questions.explanation:
Epidemiology
  • Most common type of vasculitis in adults (usually >50 years old) (Option B)

Pathophysiology
  • T cell-mediated immune response against vessel wall antigens.
  • Contributions from pro-inflammatory cytokines (particularly TNF) and anti-Endothelial Cell antibodies can be seen.
  • An association with MHC class II haplotypes can be seen.

Features
  • Fever.
  • Anaemia (normocytic normochromic).
  • High ESR.
  • Headaches (most common).
  • Jaw claudication (most specific symptom).
  • Sudden blindness (due to involvement of ophthalmic artery).
  • Associated with polymyalgia rheumatica. (Option D)

Arteries affected
  • Temporal artery (most commonly involved).
  • Vertebral artery.
  • Ophthalmic artery.
  • Aorta (giant cell aortitis).

Treatment
  • High dose corticosteroid
  • Steroid sparing agents
    • Tocilizumab
    • Methotrexate
  • Aspirin may also be used

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the rubella-containing vaccine (RCV) is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: The live attenuated RA 27/3 strain is used in the rubella vaccine

options.label: B
options.text: RCVs have a shelf-life of 2-3 years when stored at 4°C

options.label: C
options.text: The recommended dose of RCV is 1.0 ml injected subcutaneously

options.label: D
options.text: Recipients of RCV are advised not to become pregnant for 1 month after vaccination

questions.correct_answer: C. The recommended dose of RCV is 1.0 ml injected subcutaneously
questions.explanation:
RUBELLA VACCINE AND VACCINATION STRATEGY

Strain Used

Live attenuated RA 27/3 (Option A ruled out)

Formulations

Monovalent, MR, MMR, MMRV

Dosage

Single 0.5 ml dose, subcutaneously in anterolateral thigh or outer upper arm. (Option C)

Dose Effectiveness

Single-Dose Strategy: Effective for rubella elimination if high coverage is achieved. >95% effectiveness for a single dose

Two-Dose Strategy: Practical when combined with measles vaccination using MR or MMR vaccine

Storage Conditions

RCVs: 2-8°C, protected from light

Diluent vials: Ambient temperature, not frozen

Shelf-Life

2-3 years at 4°C (Option B ruled out)

Target Groups

Priority 1: Non-pregnant women of reproductive age

Priority 2: Children between 1-14 years

Priority 3: Routine vaccination of children <1 year

Pregnancy Advisory

Recipients advised not to become pregnant for 1 month after vaccination as it increases the risk of congenital rubella syndrome. (Option D ruled out)

But it is not an indication for MTP if the woman does get pregnant within 1 month of vaccination

questions.text: Correctly match the following statements with True(T)/ False(F) 1) Continuity is disrupted in tangentiality 2) Goal is not reached in circumstantiality 3) Perseveration is associated with organic mental disorder 4) Continuity is preserved in perseveration 5) Thought blocking is associated with schizophrenia
questions.explanation:
Continuity maintained with increased speed:
  • Flight of ideas: rapid flow of ideas from one to another, connected and partially understandable
  • Prolixity: Milder form of flight of ideas
  • Clang association: sentences with rhyming

Continuity maintained with decreased speed: (Statement-1)
  • Thought slowing/retardation: Decrease in speed of thought, seen in depression
  • Circumstantiality: Overinclusion of trivial and unnecessary details, but ultimately reaches the answer. (Statement-2)
  • Tangentiality: Flow of irrelevant thoughts that deviates from the main topic and never reaches the answer.

Continuity disrupted:

  • Perseveration: (Statement-4)
    • Same thought persists beyond the point of relevance.
    • Pathological repetition of the same response to different stimuli.
    • Seen in organic mental disorder (Statement-3) and schizophrenia.
  • Thought blocking:
    • Sudden arrest of thought and then the person resumes with an entirely new thought.
    • Seen in schizophrenia. (Statement-5)

questions.text: Consider the following statements: i) f IPV is a live attenuated vaccine. ii) fIPV is not effective in control of epidemics iii) OPV has a shorter shelf life than IPV iv) fIPV provides humoral immunity only v) 5 ml of fIPV is administered via IM route Which of the following are correct?
questions.explanation:
Feature IPV (Inactivated Poliovirus Vaccine) OPV (Oral Poliovirus Vaccine)
Type of Vaccine Inactivated (killed) virus Live attenuated virus
Route of Administration Intramuscular (IM) or Intradermal (ID) Oral (drops)
Immunity Provided Systemic (humoral) immunity Systemic + mucosal immunity (gut immunity)
Effectiveness in Epidemics Not effective in stopping transmission Highly effective in epidemic control
Prevention of Virus Shedding Limited effect on intestinal virus shedding Strong gut immunity prevents shedding
Shelf Life & Storage More stable, longer shelf life Less stable, requires strict cold chain
Risk of Vaccine-Derived Poliovirus (VDPV) No risk of VDPV Small risk of VDPV due to live virus reversion
Use in Eradication Programs Primarily used in polio-free areas Used in endemic and outbreak settings

  • Terminal movements are restricted by 25%

Normal or haziness of the articular margins

 

Stage II: Early Arthritis

(Option B)
  • Early joint pain, stiffness
  • Increased FADIR (Flexion, Adduction, Internal Rotation)
  • Apparent shortening due to FADIR
  •  
  • Gluteal and Quadriceps muscle wasting
  • ROM restricted by 50%

Osteopenia and narrowing of joint space

Stage III: Late Arthritis

(Option C)
  • Marked FADIR
  • True shortening
  • Gross restriction of movements (usually >50%)

Marked subchondral erosion and destruction

Stage IV: Pathological Dislocation

/severe arthritis

 
  • Marked FADIR
  • Gross shortening
  • Severe destruction and loss of joint space
  • "Wandering/traveling Acetabulum": Pathological dislocation/subluxation due to gross destruction of the femoral head or the superior acetabular margin.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true regarding the neonatal conditions described? Mastitis neonatorum typically presents with bilateral breast swelling Vaginal bleeding in neonates usually resolves within 10 days. Hymenal tags are usually symptomatic and often require medical treatment. Term neonates can lose up to 10% of their birth weight in the first week of life. Physiologic phimosis usually resolves by age 3-5 and is generally asymptomatic. Preterm infants regain their birth weight within 7-10 days.
questions.explanation:
Condition

Features

Duration

Management

Mastitis Neonatorum
  • Infection of breast tissue related to maternal hormones.
  • Symptoms include unilateral breast swelling, erythema, warmth, tenderness, and possible purulent discharge. (Statement 1)

Resolves within a few weeks

Antibiotics; usually resolve on their own

Vaginal Bleeding
  • Normal due to decreased maternal estrogen.
  • Symptoms include a small amount of blood-tinged discharge or bleeding.

Resolves within 10 days

Medical evaluation if bleeding persists or if other concerns arise

Hymenal Tags

  • Benign remnants of tissue at the vaginal opening.
  • Normal anatomical variations and typically asymptomatic.

Often resolves on its own (Statement 3)

Treatment only if causing discomfort

Physiologic Weight Loss
  • Expected weight loss in the first week of life.
  • Term neonates lose 7-10% of birth weight; preterm infants lose 10-15%.
  • They then gain about 20 to 40 grams daily.
  • This initial weight loss is primarily due to the loss of extracellular fluid, while subsequent weight gain is attributed to increased intracellular water and solids, supporting cellular growth.

Term infants regain within 7-10 days; preterm infants by 10-14 days (Statement 6)

Weight gain of 20-40 grams daily after regaining birth weight.

Physiologic Phimosis
  • A normal condition where the foreskin cannot be retracted due to preputial adhesion.
  • Generally asymptomatic.
  • This differs from pathologic phimosis which involves scarring or inflammation, which may need treatment.

The prepuce becomes retractable by 3 yr of age. Resolves by age 3-5; may take longer

Gentle retraction during bathing to aid in loosening.

A 32-year-old pregnant woman presents at 30 weeks of gestation with BP of 170/110 mmHg and proteinuria. She is stable without evidence of end-organ damage. According to the algorithm for managing severe preeclampsia, what is the recommended management approach?

options.label: B
options.text: Consider expectant management in a tertiary care centre

options.label: C
options.text: Monitor closely for 24 hours and discharge

options.label: D
options.text: Administer antenatal corticosteroids and terminate pregnancy

questions.correct_answer: B. Consider expectant management in a tertiary care centre
questions.explanation:
Algorithm for Treating Preeclampsia

Initial Evaluation
  • Perform comprehensive maternal and fetal evaluation.
  • CBC with platelet estimate, serum creatinine, LDH, AST, ALT, and proteinuria testing.
  • Fetal evaluation: USG for estimated fetal weight, amniotic fluid volume, and fetal antepartum testing.

Decision for Delivery vs Expectant Management
  • 34+ Weeks Gestation: Deliver promptly upon maternal stabilization or with labor/prelabor rupture of membranes; do not delay for steroid administration.
  • Before 34 Weeks Gestation with Severe Preeclampsia: Consider expectant management in a tertiary care setting if maternal and fetal conditions are stable.
  • 37+ Weeks Gestation with Gestational Hypertension or Preeclampsia Without Severe Features: Opt for delivery rather than expectant management upon diagnosis.
  • Before 37 Weeks Gestation with Gestational Hypertension or Preeclampsia Without Severe Features: Managed as an outpatient; requires frequent fetal and maternal evaluation. Deliver only if specific conditions necessitate immediate intervention.

Management During Expectant Management
  • Closely monitor maternal and fetal conditions.
  • Serial laboratory testing: CBC, liver enzymes, serum creatinine.
  • Use antihypertensive therapy for acute-onset severe hypertension (systolic ≥160 mm Hg or diastolic ≥110 mm Hg).
  • Administer antenatal corticosteroids and monitor for 48 hours if delivery is indicated before 34 weeks gestation. 

Regularly check for Conditions Necessitating Delivery Regardless of Gestational Age

Maternal Conditions

Fetal Conditions
  • HELLP syndrome
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Eclampsia
  • Suspected acute placental abruption, or vaginal bleeding without placenta previa
  • Uncontrolled severe-range blood pressure
  • Worsening renal function
  • Persistent headaches, epigastric/right upper quadrant pain
  • Visual disturbances
  • Motor deficits
  • Altered sensorium
  • Stroke
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Abnormal fetal testing
  • Fetal death
  • Fetus with low survival likelihood (lethal anomaly, Extreme prematurity)
  • Persistent reversed end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery

Postpartum Management
  • Monitor blood pressure and symptoms post-delivery.
  • Consider NSAIDs for pain management instead of opioids.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of urinary leakage. She reports that she leaks urine when she coughs, sneezes, or exercises. She also experiences occasional sudden urges to urinate that she cannot control, especially when she hears running water or after holding her urine for some time. Which types of urinary incontinence are likely present in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Stress urinary incontinence

Involuntary loss of urine with effort or physical exertion or when sneezing or coughing.

Urgency urinary incontinence

Involuntary loss of urine associated with urgency or sudden, compelling desire to void that is difficult to defer.

Mixed urinary incontinence

Involuntary loss of urine associated with urgency and with physical exertion, sneezing or coughing.

Overactive bladder

Urinary urgency, typically accompanied by frequency and nocturia, with or without urge urinary incontinence, in the absence of urinary tract infection or other obvious pathology.

Nocturnal enuresis

Involuntary loss of urine that occurs during sleep.

Functional urinary incontinence

Involuntary loss of urine that is due to cognitive, functional, or mobility impairments in the presence of an intact lower urinary tract system.

Match the following newer hypolipidemic drugs with their corresponding Mechanisms of Action (MOAs): Drug Mechanisms of Action 1. Ezetimibe A. Inhibition of cholesterol absorption in the intestines 2. Alirocumab B. Inhibition of PCSK9 enzyme 3. Lomitapide C. Inhibition of microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) 4. Bempedoic acid D. Inhibition of ATP citrate lyase
questions.explanation:
Ezetimibe
  • Disrupts cholesterol and phytosterol absorption in small intestines via PCIL1 transporter protein interference.
  • Ezetimibe, with statins, enhances LDL-C reduction by inhibiting statin-induced cholesterol synthesis rise.
  • Primarily used with statins for primary hypercholesterolemia.
  • Avoid combining with bile acid sequestrants due to inhibited ezetimibe absorption.

PCSK9 inhibitors

  • PCSK9 inhibitors: Monoclonal antibodies block PCSK9 action, promoting LDL receptor recycling and degradation, enhancing LDL clearance.
  • Alirocumab and evolocumab: Lower LDL-C in familial hypercholesterolemia or cardiovascular disease,given subcutaneously every 2 weeks or monthly, complement statins to reduce LDL-C.
  • Inclisiran, a new drug which is a silencing RNA.

Lomitapide
  • An inhibitor of microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP).
  • Action on MTP hinders the production of VLDLs in liver cells and chylomicrons in the intestinal epithelial cells.

Omega 3 fatty acids
  • Present in fish
  • Deacreses FFA delivery to liver and decreases activity of TG synthesizing enzymes.
  • Decrease VLDL production in liver
  • Drugs: Eicosa penta enoic acid (Icosapent), Docosa hexa enoic acid

Bempedoic acid

  • A prodrug, transforms into its active state, bempedoic acid-CoA which competitively blocks ATP Citrate Lyase, diminishing the production of hepatic cholesterol synthesis by limiting the flow of acetyl-CoA to HMG-CoA reductase.

questions.text: Match the following coronary arteries with the areas of the heart they predominantly supply: Coronary Arteries Supplied Areas 1) Right conus artery a) Anterior 2/3 of interventricular septum 2) Left anterior descending artery (LAD) b) Infundibulum of right ventricle 3) Left circumflex artery (LCX) c) Posterior interventricular septum 4) Posterior descending artery (PDA) d) Lateral wall of the left ventricle e) Apex of the heart
questions.explanation:
Artery

Supplied Region

Right Conus Artery (RCA)

Infundibulum of the right ventricle

Left Anterior Descending (LAD)

Anterior 2/3 of the interventricular septum

Left Circumflex Artery (LCX)

Lateral wall of the left ventricle

Posterior Descending Artery (PDA)

Posterior interventricular septum

Artery

Right Coronary Artery (RCA)

Left Coronary Artery (LCA)

Origin

Arises from the right aortic sinus.

Arises from the left aortic sinus.

Course

Moves forward between the pulmonary trunk and right auricle, descending in the right atrioventricular groove.

Passes forward between the pulmonary trunk and the left auricle, and then splits into two main branches.

Branches

Right Conus Artery:

  • Supplies the pulmonary conus (infundibulum) and the upper right ventricle.
 

Anterior Ventricular Branches:

  • 2 or 3 in number - supply the anterior surface of the right ventricle.
 

Right Marginal Artery:

  • Largest of anterior ventricular branches - runs along the right margin of the heart towards the apex.
 

Posterior Descending Artery (PDA) or the posterior interventricular artery:

  • Travels in the posterior interventricular groove, supplying the inferior wall of both ventricles and the posterior part of the interventricular septum.
  • This artery often arises from the RCA but can also originate from the LCA in some individuals.
 

Atrial Branches:

  • Supply the right atrium and contribute to the SA node in some individuals.

Left Anterior Descending Artery (LAD):

  • Travels down the anterior interventricular groove to the heart’s apex.
  • It supplies both ventricles and the anterior two-thirds of the interventricular septum.
 

Left Circumflex Artery (LCX): Circles around the left margin of the heart in the atrioventricular groove, giving off:

 
  • Left Marginal Artery: Supplies the left margin of the left ventricle.
  • Anterior and Posterior Ventricular Branches: Supply the left ventricle.
  • Atrial Branches: Supply the left atrium.
 

Lateral or diagonal artery - larger ventricular branch - may arise directly from the trunk of the left coronary artery.

  • A small left conus artery supplies the pulmonary conus.

questions.text: Match the following 1. Leishman Donovan bodies a) 2. Dohle bodies b) 3. Henderson Petersen bodies c) 4. Cowdry Type A bodies d)
questions.explanation:
Histopathological Bodies in Microbiology

Leishman Donovan (LD) bodies

  • Found in untreated leishmaniasis.
  • They are light blue, ellipsoid structures measuring 2-4 μm in length.
  • LD bodies have an eccentric nucleus and a smaller kinetosome at the opposite pole.
  • These bodies are located within large macrophages (also known as Wright's cells).

Dohle bodies

  • Light blue-grey, oval, basophilic staining inclusions were found in the cytoplasm of neutrophils in the peripheral smear.
  • Seen in bacterial infections like tuberculosis, diphtheria, and typhoid,
  • Indicate defective neutrophil production and maturation.

Hendersen Petersen bodies

  • Molluscum contagiosum, caused by a poxvirus, is characterised by the presence of large, ellipsoid intracytoplasmic inclusions in the stratum spinosum and corneum of infected skin known as Henderson-Peterson bodies.
  • They are made up of nuclear and cytoplasmic protein aggregates and mark the site of viral replication.

Councilman Bodies

  • Acidophilic inclusion bodies are found in the cytoplasm of hepatocytes in viral infections like hepatitis and yellow fever.
  • These bodies result from hepatocyte apoptosis and are associated with ballooning degeneration of liver cells.

Cowdry Type A bodies

  • Cowdry bodies are eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions made of nucleic acid and protein, seen in infections like herpes, yellow fever, polio, and adenovirus.
  • Type A (found in herpes and yellow fever) appears as droplet-like masses with clear halos and chromatin margination around the nucleus.
  • Type B (associated with polio and adenovirus) lacks nuclear changes.

Negri bodies

  • Negri bodies are eosinophilic, cytoplasmic inclusion bodies found in neurons, primarily in rabies infection.
  • They represent sites of viral replication and are considered a hallmark of rabies in histopathological examination.

Torres bodies

The intranuclear inclusion body seen in liver cells infected with the yellow fever virus is composed of host proteins.

questions.text: A 32-year-old HIV-positive male presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of worsening shortness of breath, dry cough, and fever. He reports significant weight loss over the past month and has a CD4 count of 150 cells/mm³. HRCT Thorax shows ground-glass opacities. A bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) is performed, and a histological examination shows organisms with a characteristic appearance, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Pneumocystis jirovecii

Morphology
  1. Trophozoite - thin-walled, irregularly shaped, 1-5 µm in size
  2. Precyst - an intermediate stage of the sexual phase, 5-8 µm in size
  3. Cyst - thick-walled, spherical, containing up to 8 intracystic bodies and up to 8 µm in size

Risk factors
  • HIV: CD4 < 200
  • Primary immunodeficiency states
  • Transplant recipients
  • Hematological malignancies

Clinical features

transmitted by respiratory droplets and is asymptomatic in immunocompetent individuals. In immunocompromised patients, life-threatening pneumonia develops.

PCP - Pneumocystis Carinii pneumonia

  • Dyspnoea
  • Dry cough
  • Fever
  • Weight loss
  • B/L interstitial pneumonia

Diagnosis
  • GMS / Giemsa stain- mc used
  • Giemsa, toluidine blue, methenamine silver, and calcofluor white stains can demonstrate trophozoites - cyst wall is black with a methenamine silver stain.

Crushed Ping Pong ball (also called Helmet/Hat or Cup and Saucer appearance).

 

  • The β-d-glucan test has proven to be quite useful for rapid diagnosis of Pneumocystis pneumonia with a high degree of sensitivity and specificity.

Treatment
  • The cornerstone for both prevention and treatment is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.
 
  • Alternative therapies have been used in AIDS patients; they include pentamidine, trimethoprim-dapsone, clindamycin-primaquine, atovaquone, and trimetrexate.

questions.explanation:
Definition

Rupture of the tunica albuginea surrounding the corpora cavernosa, typically due to blunt trauma to an erect penis.

Clinical Features

Triad Symptoms:

  • Audible Pop or Crack: Reported during trauma.
  • Pain: Severe at the time of injury.
  • Swelling and Bruising: Noticeable swelling and discoloration.
 

Eggplant Deformity:

  • Characteristic appearance due to extensive swelling and hematoma, associated with significant pain and discoloration.
 

Blood at Urethral Meatus: Indicates possible urethral injury.

Investigations
  • Physical Examination: Initial assessment.
  • Ultrasound: Evaluates injury extent and hematomas.
  • Retrograde Urethrogram (RGU): Checks for urethral injury.

Management

Immediate Care:

  • Ice packs to reduce swelling
  • Pain management with analgesics

Surgical Intervention:

  • Repair of the ruptured tunica albuginea and any urethral injury

Postoperative Care:

  • Antibiotics to prevent infection

Complications
  • Penile Deformity: Possible curvature or fibrosis.
  • Erectile Dysfunction: Potential if injury or repair is inadequate.

questions.text: Match the following images with appropriate tests. 1. a) Dugas test 2. b) Callaway test 3. c) Hamilton ruler test 4. d) Regimen batch sign
questions.explanation:
Tests of Shoulder dislocation

Hamilton's ruler test

Measures the distance from the acromion to the lateral epicondyle with the arm in a neutral position. A lack of gap between the arm and the ruler indicates dislocation.

Dugas test

The inability to touch the opposite shoulder with a shoulder dislocation is typically observed in anterior dislocations.

 

Callaway test

The circumference of the axilla is checked bilaterally using a measuring tape. An increased circumference on the affected side is diagnostic of dislocation.

Bryants test

It involves observing the anterior axillary fold, displaced inferiorly on the affected side in shoulder dislocation.

Regimen batch sign

Loss of sensation over the deltoid on the affected side due to axillary nerve damage.

questions.text: Match the type of cyst with the correct description of it. Types of Cysts Description 1. Functional cyst A. A mucus-filled cyst on the cervix 2. Gartner’s cyst B. Forms due to remnants of the Wolffian duct 3. Skene’s cyst C. Located near the urethra in females 4. Nabothian cyst D. Commonly occurs in the ovaries
questions.explanation:
Type of Cyst

Description

Details

Functional Cyst

Fluid-filled sacs that form on the ovaries, typically during the menstrual cycle.

 

 
  •  2 Types:
    1. Follicular cysts form due to hormonal dysfunction prior to ovulation, leading to expansion of the follicular antrum with serous fluid.
    2. Corpus luteum cysts form due to excessive hemorrhage from the vascular corpus luteum following ovulation.
  • High-dose combination oral contraceptives (COCs) suppress ovarian activity and protect against cyst development.
  • Surgical excision is considered for large, persistent cysts or smaller ones causing persistent symptoms. Usually benign and not cancerous.

Gartner’s Cyst

Forms from remnants of the Wolffian duct
  • Located along vaginal walls
  • Can cause discomfort, urinary issues, or dyspareunia if large
  • Treatment may involve surgical removal if symptomatic

Skene’s Cyst

Located near the urethra in females, formed from the Skene’s glands.
  • Involved in lubrication of the urethral opening. Usually presents as a urethral diverticulum.
  • Cysts here can cause urinary problems, pain, or discomfort.
  • Treatment may include antibiotics for infection or surgical drainage/removal if necessary.

Nabothian Cyst

Mucus-filled cysts that occur on the cervix.
  • Form when mucus-producing glands in the cervix are covered by skin cells, trapping the mucus.
  • Generally harmless, asymptomatic and often found during routine pelvic exams.
  • No treatment is typically required unless they cause significant symptoms, in which case they can be drained or removed.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a chronic cough and shortness of breath. Upon further inquiry, it is revealed that he has been a smoker for 20 years, averaging a pack a day. His doctor discusses the risks of smoking and recommends nicotine cessation drugs to help him quit. Which of the following may be prescribed first-line?
questions.explanation:
Mechanism of Action

Effect on Smoking Cessation

First-Line Drugs

    

Bupropion
(Option D)

Blocks reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine in the brain

Reduces nicotine withdrawal symptoms and cravings

Nicotine Replacement Therapy (NRT)

Provides controlled nicotine dose (patches, gum, lozenges, inhalers). Never given orally, sublingual due to its fast absorption

Alleviates withdrawal symptoms and cravings, gradually reducing nicotine dependence

Varenicline

Binds to nicotine receptors in the brain, partially stimulating them.

Most effective drug.

Reduces cravings and pleasurable effects of smoking.

Used in tobacco chewing.
S/E: Depression (suicides)

All first-line drugs are C/I in seizures and heart diseases (MI, angina, hypertension)

Second-Line Drugs

    

Clonidine
(Option B)

Alpha-2 adrenergic agonist, reduces sympathetic nervous system activity

Alleviates withdrawal symptoms such as anxiety, irritability, and restlessness.
Safe in patients with heart disease/seizure.

Nortriptyline

(Option C)

Tricyclic antidepressant, affecting norepinephrine and serotonin levels

Reduces withdrawal symptoms and cravings

Topiramate

(Option A)

Blocks glutamate receptors and facilitates GABA neurotransmission

Potentially facilitates smoking cessation

Mecamylamine

Blocks nicotine receptors in the brain

Reduces the rewarding effects of nicotine, making smoking less appealing.

Used in nicotine poisoning.

First line

Second line

Nicotine

Clonidine (safe in heart diseases)

Varenicline

Nortriptyline

Bupropion

Off-label: Topiramate/ Mecamylamine

questions.text: Match the following: Disease Mammography features a. Fibroadenoma (i) Eggshell calcification b. Fat Necrosis (ii) Broken-needle appearance c. Duct ectasia (iii) Teacup calcification d. Fibrocystic disease (iv) Popcorn calcifications
questions.explanation:
Condition

Mammographic Findings

Fibroadenoma

Round, well-circumscribed mass with smooth borders; "popcorn" calcifications in older lesions. Benign.

Fat Necrosis

Irregular, spiculated mass with calcifications; central fat density - Eggshell calcification. Often mimics malignancy.

Ductal Carcinoma in Situ (DCIS)

Microcalcifications (Segmental distribution of pleomorphic microcalcifications), often linear or branching, are associated with malignancy.

Invasive Ductal Carcinoma

Irregular, spiculated mass with poorly defined margins. Microcalcifications and architectural distortion.

Fibrocystic disease

Teacup calcification represents the layering out of calcific material in the dependent portion of microcysts on a lateral magnification view.

Duct ectasia

Broken-needle appearance, typical of duct ectasia. Sometimes thicker, more localized calcifications can be seen, giving a ‘lead-pipe’ appearance.

A 55-year-old man presents with severe shortness of breath, cough, and fever after recent bacterial pneumonia. Physical examination shows tachypnea, hypoxia, and diffuse crackles on chest auscultation. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral opacities suggestive of pulmonary oedema. Histopathological examination of lung biopsy shows congested, edematous lungs with inflammation. Which histopathological finding is characteristic of the acute exudative stage in this patient's lung injury?

options.label: B
options.text: Formation of fibrotic thickening in the alveolar septa

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of waxy hyaline membranes lining the alveolar walls

options.label: D
options.text: Resolution of granulation tissue in the alveolar spaces

questions.correct_answer: C. Presence of waxy hyaline membranes lining the alveolar walls
questions.explanation:
Stage

Features

1. Acute Exudative Stage
  • Lungs appear heavy, firm, red, and boggy.
  • Manifestations include congestion, interstitial and intra-alveolar oedema, inflammation, fibrin deposition, and diffuse alveolar damage.
  • Alveolar walls are lined with “waxy hyaline membranes” composed of fibrin-rich oedema fluid mixed with remnants of necrotic epithelial cells.

2. Proliferative or Organizing Stage
  • Proliferation of Type II pneumocytes.
  • Granulation tissue forms in the alveolar walls and spaces.

3. Late Fibrotic Stage
  • Fibrotic thickening of alveolar septa indicates persistent fibrosis and scarring that may develop in some cases of lung injury.

questions.text: A 22-year-old college student is brought to the emergency department by his friends after exhibiting bizarre behavior at a party. He appears disoriented, has dilated pupils, and reports seeing vivid colors and patterns. His vital signs show tachycardia and mild hypertension. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Chemical nature

Synthetic base derived from lysergic acid nucleus from ergot alkaloids

Common forms

Tablets, liquid, blotter paper ("blotter acid")

Potency

100 µg of LSD ≈ 10-15 mg of psilocybin ≈ 300-400 mg of mescaline

Onset and duration

Onset within an hour, peaks in 2-4 hours, lasts 8-12 hours

Common physiologic symptoms

• Dilated pupils

• Increased deep tendon motor reflexes

• Muscle tension

• Mild motor incoordination

• Ataxia

Occasional physiologic symptoms

• Increased heart rate

• Increased respiration

• Hypertension

• Nausea

• Decreased appetite

• Salivation

• Sweating

• Blurred vision

Psychological effects

• Visual and perceptual changes

• Altered sense of time

• Mood changes

• Possible anxiety or paranoia

• Possible feelings of insight or creativity

Associated phenomenon

• Flashback phenomenon

• Badtrip (also seen with cannabis)

• Reflex hallucination/ morbid synesthesia (may occur with other hallucinogens)

Tolerance

Develops quickly (2-3 days of repeated use), lost after 4-6 days of abstinence

Potential risks

• Accidents due to impaired judgment

• Rarely, a syndrome similar to neuroleptic malignant syndrome

• Possible triggering of anxiety or depression in some users

questions.explanation:
MALIGNANT MESOTHELIOMA

About
  • Highly aggressive malignancy originating from pleural mesothelial cells, strongly linked to asbestos.
  • The most common primary pleural tumour.

Diagnosis
  • Imaging:
    • CXR, CT, MRI, FDG-PET: Assess tumour invasion and metastasis
    • ECG: Checks for cardiac involvement
  • Biopsy: Pleural Biopsy: Via thoracoscopy, thoracentesis, or open techniques.
  • Immunhistochemistry findings:

Diagnosis

Mesothelioma

Adenocarcinoma

Carcinoembryonic Antigen (CEA)

Negative

Positive

(Options A & C ruled out)

Vimentin

Positive

Negative

(Option D ruled out)

Low Molecular Weight Cytokines

Positive

Negative

Electron Microscopy

Long, sinuous villi

Short, straight villi with fuzzy glycocalyx
 
  • Staging: Based on tumour invasion (T), lymph node involvement (N), and metastasis (M).

Treatment

Multimodality Therapy:

  • Early-stage: Surgery (EPP or EPD) with cisplatin-based chemotherapy and radiotherapy.
  • Advanced Disease: Chemotherapy may extend survival but not cure.
  • Palliative Care: Pleural catheters, pleurodesis.

Surgical Options:

  • Extrapleural Pneumonectomy (EPP): Complete lung resection; higher risk but more extensive.
  • Extended Pleurectomy and Decortication (EPD): Lung-preserving, safer, preferred in many centres.

Prognosis

Median survival is 24–36 months depending on stage and treatment.

Diagnosis

Mesothelioma

Adenocarcinoma

Carcinoembryonic Antigen (CEA)

Negative

Positive

questions.explanation:
Criminal Abortion - Legal Aspects

BNS

(Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023)

IPC Section

(Indian Penal Code, 1860)

Definition

88

(Option A ruled out)

312

Voluntary criminal abortion by anyone, including the pregnant woman, can lead to up to 3 years imprisonment and/or fine.

If the woman is "quick with child" (fetal movement felt), the punishment can extend up to 7 years and a fine.

89

(Option B)

313

Causing a miscarriage without the woman’s consent is punishable by life imprisonment or up to 10 years in prison, with a fine.

90

(Option C ruled out)

314

If a miscarriage attempt leads to the woman’s death, the responsible person faces up to 10 years in prison and a fine.

If done without her consent, the punishment can be life imprisonment or up to 10 years.

91

(Option D ruled out)

315

Actions to prevent a child from being born alive or causing death after birth can result in up to 10 years imprisonment, fine, or both.

92

316

Causing the death of a "quick unborn child" (after fetal movement) is considered culpable homicide, punishable by up to 10 years imprisonment and a fine.

questions.text: Which of the following features correctly describes the conditions depicted in images 1 and 2? a) Severe wasting b) Flaky paint dermatitis c) Baggy pants d) Skin and bone appearance e) Nutritional anaemia f) Sugar baby g) Flag sign h) Monkey facies
questions.explanation:
MARASMUS

KWASHIORKOR
  • Severe wasting of fat and muscle.
  • Often due to acute starvation or illness secondary to poor nutritional status.
  • Severe marasmus is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM).
  • Skin-and-bones appearance.
  • Monkey facies due to the loss of buccal fat pads.
  • Baggy pants appearance- due to loose skin hanging from the buttocks.
  • Loss of axillary fat pad.
  • Despite the severe wasting, affected children may appear alert.
  • No oedema.
  • Pitting oedema present.
  • “Well-fed” / “Sugar baby” appearance of the child d/t oedema.
  • Oedema can be mild to severe, representing 5-20% of body weight.
  • Muscle wasting is present.
  • Flaky pain dermatitis present (peeling skin).
  • Mucous membrane lesions- smooth tongue, cheilosis, angular stomatitis.
  • Flag sign in hair- alternating pigmented bands. Hair is sparse.
  • Unhappiness, apathy, irritability, and feeding difficulties.
  • Anorexia, vomiting, abdominal distension, and diarrhoea.
  • Nutritional anaemia is typically present.
  • Cardiovascular issues include cold, pale extremities, prolonged circulation time, bradycardia, and hypotension.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl presents with fever, sore throat, and a red, finely papular rash that started on her neck and spread to her body. The rash is more pronounced in the skin creases, and her examination reveals the findings in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Scarlet Fever

Group A Streptococcus (GAS) pharyngitis is associated with a characteristic rash caused due to a pyrogenic exotoxin (erythrogenic toxin) produced by GAS in individuals lacking antitoxin antibodies.

Caused By

Group A Streptococcus (GAS)

Incidence and Virulence

Less common and less virulent now compared to the past, with incidence depending on toxin strains and the population immunity.

Clinical Features
  • Rash appears within 24-48 hours, starting around the neck and spreading to the trunk and extremities.
  • Rash is a diffuse, finely papular, erythematous eruption causing bright-red discoloration, which blanches on pressure.
  • Rash is accentuated in the creases of the elbow, axilla, and groin (Pastia lines) and gives the skin a goose-pimple appearance.
  • Erythematous cheeks with pallor around the mouth.
  • After 3-4 days, the rash fades, followed by desquamation starting on the face and progressing downward.
  • Desquamation may occur around fingernails, palms, and soles.
  • Tongue is coated with swollen papillae, which later give a "strawberry tongue" appearance after desquamation.
  • Pharyngitis.

Diagnosis
  • Classic scarlet fever is typically straightforward to diagnose.
  • A history of recent exposure to GAS is helpful.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying GAS in the pharynx.

Treatment

  • Antibiotic therapy should be started immediately.
  • Drug of choice: Penicillin or amoxicillin for 10 days.
  • Alternative for Penicillin Allergy: Oral cephalosporins, clindamycin, Macrolides (erythromycin, clarithromycin) for 10 days or azalide (azithromycin) for 5 days.
  • Injection: Benzathine penicillin G single dose intramuscular injection for those unlikely to complete oral therapy.

Complication

  • Suppurative Complications:
    • Cervical lymphadenitis
    • Peritonsillar abscess
    • Retropharyngeal abscess
    • Otitis media
    • Mastoiditis
    • Sinusitis
    • Group A Streptococcus (GAS) pneumonia
  • Nonsuppurative Complications:
    • Acute rheumatic fever
    • Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Image

White strawberry tongue (first day)

Red strawberry tongue (third day)

questions.text: Which of the following is the comprehensive program the Ministry of Women and Child Development launched to combat trafficking?
questions.explanation:
The Ujjawala scheme

The Ujjawala scheme, launched in India on December 4, 2007, by the Ministry of Women and Child Development, is a comprehensive program to combat trafficking. The scheme is primarily implemented through NGOs.

Objectives/Goals

Strategies to Achieve Goals

Prevention

  • Formation of community vigilance and adolescent groups, awareness creation
  • preparation of IEC (Information, Education, Communication) material, organization of workshops.

Rescue
  • Safe withdrawal of victims from the place of exploitation.

Rehabilitation
  • Providing safe shelter, basic amenities, medical care, legal aid, vocational training, and employment opportunities to victims.

Reintegration
  • Supporting victims in their reintegration into society.

Repatriation

  • Providing support to cross-border victims for their safe return to their home countries.

  • Extent: Base of skull to coccyx
  • Location: Between vertebrae on one side and prevertebral muscles and the prevertebral fascia on the other

Aetiology

  • Mild dysphagia

Treatment

questions.text: A 38-year-old premenopausal woman is diagnosed with Lobular Carcinoma In Situ (LCIS) after a breast biopsy. She opts for chemoprevention as her management strategy. Her doctor discusses various medication options with her. Which of the following statements about chemoprevention for LCIS is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Chemoprevention eliminates the risk of developing breast cancer

options.label: B
options.text: Tamoxifen reduces breast cancer risk by 25% over 5 years

options.label: C
options.text: Chemoprevention is only effective for the ipsilateral breast

options.label: D
options.text: Tamoxifen reduces breast cancer risk by 56% over 5 years

questions.correct_answer: D. Tamoxifen reduces breast cancer risk by 56% over 5 years
questions.explanation:
Overview
  • Histologic marker of increased breast cancer risk, not true cancer.
  • It involves an abnormal proliferation of cells within the lobules of the breast without invasion through the basement membrane.
  • Subsequent invasive cancers are predominantly ductal, not lobular
Characteristics
  • Occurs mainly in younger, premenopausal women
  • Typically an incidental finding during biopsy
  • No palpable masses or suspicious mammographic microcalcifications
  • Bilateral
Risk
  • 21.4% chance of developing carcinoma over 35 years
  • 7:1 risk ratio for invasive breast cancer
  • 50% of subsequent carcinomas in contralateral breast
Management
  • Close observation
  • Chemoprevention
    • Medications: Tamoxifen, Raloxifene, or Arimidex
    • Tamoxifen reduces risk by 56% over 5 years
  • Surgical: Bilateral mastectomy (if surgery chosen prophylactically)

Clinical Significance
  • Lifelong breast cancer risk affecting both breasts equally 
  • Risk slightly less than 1% per year

A 35-year-old woman with regular menstrual cycles undergoes routine Pap smear screening, which reveals a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL) of the cervix. Further testing confirms infection with high-risk HPV type 16. Which of the following mechanisms regarding the oncogenic activity of E6 and E7 of HPV is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: E6 protein inhibits the degradation of p53.

options.label: B
options.text: E6 stimulates the expression of TERT.

options.label: D
options.text: E7 can inactivate cyclins A and E

questions.correct_answer: B. E6 stimulates the expression of TERT.
questions.explanation:
Oncogenic Activities of E6 Protein

Oncogenic Activities of E7 Protein
  • Binds to and promotes degradation of p53 → Impairs cell growth and apoptosis regulation (Option A).
  • Stimulates expression of TERT (telomerase reverse transcriptase) → Facilitates cellular immortalisation by maintaining telomere length.
  • Disrupts interaction between RB protein and E2F transcription factors
  • Inactivates CDK inhibitors (e.g., p21 and p27) (Option C).
  • Activates cyclins A and E (Option D)
 

All these mechanisms enhance cell cycle progression and cellular proliferation in HPV infections.

questions.text: Match the Following: 1) a) Bacterial Keratitis 2) b) Superficial Punctate Keratitis 3) c) Pseudodendritis 4) d) Dendritic Ulcer 5) e) Nummular Keratitis 6) f) Fungal Keratitis
questions.explanation:
Image

Description

Bacterial Keratitis:


 

A corneal epithelial defect with an infiltrate (a larger area of corneal involvement) and significant circumcorneal injection, often with a hypopyon.

Fungal Keratitis:



 

Grey or yellow-white stromal infiltrate with indistinct fluffy margins, often with satellite lesions, or a yellow-white densely suppurative infiltrate in Candida keratitis.

Superficial Punctate Keratitis:


 

This term describes any corneal epithelial disturbance with a dot-like morphology, including conditions like Thygeson superficial punctate keratitis.

Nummular Keratitis:

Characterized by fine granular subepithelial deposits surrounded by a halo of stromal haze.

Dendritic Ulcer:

Linear branching ulcer with terminal bulbs, the base of which stains well with fluorescein, and where the virus-laden cells at the margin of the ulcer stain with rose Bengal.

Pseudodendritis:

Corneal epithelial lesions that are smaller and finer than herpes simplex dendrites, have tapered ends without terminal bulbs, and stain better with rose Bengal than with fluorescein.

questions.text: Match the following images of forceps with their names. 1. a. Simpson forceps 2. b. Piper forceps 3. c. Wrigley's forceps 4.​​​​​​​ d. Kielland forceps
questions.explanation:
Instrument

Description

1. Simpson Forceps
  • Long, curved blades.
  • Sliding lock mechanism.
  • Versatile - used for outlet and low-cavity applications.
  • Accommodates various fetal head sizes.
  • One of the most commonly used forceps.

2. Wrigley's Forceps
  • Short, slightly curved blades.
  • Fixed English-style lock.
  • Designed for low or outlet forceps deliveries.
  • It is easier to manoeuvre when the fetal head is very low or visible.

3. Kielland Forceps
  • Long, almost straight blades
  • Adjustable pivot.
  • Designed for rotation of the fetal head.
  • Useful for occiput transverse positions.
  • Can accommodate asynclitism (tilted fetal head).

4. Piper Forceps
  • Asymmetrical blades (one solid, one fenestrated)
  • Specifically for the after-coming head in breech deliveries.
  • Allows application when access to the fetal head is limited.
  • Designed for quick delivery of head-in breech births.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with difficulty seeing in low light and peripheral vision loss that has gradually worsened over several years. On fundoscopy, the following findings are noted. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for these findings?

A 58-year-old female with hypertension and heart failure is prescribed an ACE inhibitor for blood pressure control. What is the most significant drug interaction to be cautious about when prescribing ACE inhibitors?
questions.explanation:
Drug Interaction

Mechanism

Clinical Implication

ACE Inhibitors + Potassium Supplements/K-sparing diuretics

Risk of hyperkalemia due to reduced aldosterone secretion by ACE inhibitors combined with potassium-retaining agents.

Monitoring serum potassium levels is crucial to avoid hyperkalemia, which can cause serious cardiac issues such as arrhythmias.

ACE Inhibitors + NSAIDs

NSAIDs can reduce the anti-hypertensive effects of ACE inhibitors and decrease renal blood flow, increasing the risk of acute renal failure (ARF) or oliguria.

Use caution when combining NSAIDs with ACE inhibitors, and closely monitor renal function, particularly in high-risk patients.

ACE Inhibitors + Lithium

ACE inhibitors can increase the reabsorption of lithium, potentially leading to lithium toxicity.

Monitor lithium levels carefully when starting or adjusting ACE inhibitors in patients taking lithium, and adjust the lithium dosage as needed.

ACE Inhibitors + Antacids

Reduced bioavailability of ACE inhibitors due to binding with antacids.

Administer ACE inhibitors at least two hours before or after antacids to maintain their efficacy.

ACE Inhibitors + Diuretics

Diuretics enhance the hypotensive effects of ACE inhibitors by depleting sodium and raising renin levels.

In patients already on diuretics, start ACE inhibitors at a low dose to minimise the risk of excessive blood pressure reduction initially.
